nodes.text: Someone tweeted it a few weeks ago but I struggle to imagine what people did in an office in say, 1985 as much as I do for 1885. Before the internet, office working life is just a black hole to me, I have no real conception of what people were up to. Typing and smoking? IDK.

@mippy @Birdyword You've just reminded me of my first job in journalism, because I did a voice test for my interview. I had to do a voiceover for a package for the next bulletin and someone whipped the video cassette out of the machine on the newsroom floor and ran off to the studio floor with it.
@Zoah_HS @JackHillcox @Kav_Kaushik @Birdyword Waiting with bated breath... https://t.co/TNntCCpdLH
@Birdyword I didn't work in an office until the 1990s, but back then we spent a LOT of time on the telephone. My main memory of the '90s in a newsroom is telephones ringing everywhere.
@Birdyword thinking, doing and writing

@Birdyword People did many of the same types of work they do today, but without the aid of computers. Paper calendars. Paper ledgers. Paper work logs. Paper requisition forms. Paper checks and cash for financial transactions. Crazy people talked about the future being paperless.
@Ray_McCann55 @MATruman @Birdyword I had an accountant shout at me because he wanted to fax accounts through before a Commissioner’s hearing and my office didn’t have a fax machine in 1991
@Birdyword My Dad used to run a Post Office. I remember lots of people writing things in books and books going to and from filing. Oh, and meeting customers face to face all the time.

@Birdyword I worked in Advertising production in the 80's. We physically had to package and courier zincos (ads imprinted on bits of metal) all over the country. We also had 3 hour lunches on a Friday and the boss would ring the pub if he wanted something

@Birdyword Even well into the 1990s, I worked with some people who were so accustomed to paper-based communication, they'd print all their emails every few hours and read and reply on paper before typing their responses and sending them via email.
@jrhopkin @DuncanWeldon @Birdyword Near full employment with wages that require a £13.7 billion annual employer subsidy to support 3.2 million people in full time work.

@Birdyword I temped in legal offices, which had an amazing internal mail system (the DX) that could apparently overnight papers to any other solicitor's office/chambers. We did mail and fax things, but correspondence with lawyers went into reusable brown envelopes, closed with a thread.
@PhilipBBerman @Birdyword Offices certainly had word processors and PCs in 1985. The function of the business didn’t change with the advent of technology.

@Birdyword 1996. Many telephone calls, calculators on every desk, massive filing cabinets, ‘active’ paper records kept in shoeboxes & ring-binders when completed. Lots of manual record-keeping. Fax machines & some PCs (no Internet at all). Small office smoking area & pub for Lunch x2 p/w.
@uccello_lirico @Birdyword A term which is unlikely to be understood by anyone under the age 40, I'd guess!
@Birdyword I just predate the internet and there was a lot of dicking about iirc
@Birdyword Larger orgs had typing pools filled with typists transforming handwritten memos into typed memos. (My wife worked in one of these, even after computers started showing up on every desk.)
@csav55 @Birdyword @eugeneh84 We also had a 'sports and social club' bar where we would have two or three pints then return to 'work'. And after work... Weird to think about it now.

@Birdyword Communication was face-to-face, via the phone, and via typed memos -- lots of memos distributed in reusable shotgun envelopes. There was interoffice mail delivery multiple times a day. Even small orgs had mailroom staff to duplicate and distribute written communication. https://t.co/eDvIVviHKC

@Stephen_May1 @Birdyword Letters. I’m just old enough to have had a job where we corresponded with customers by letter. It was seafront hotel in Brighton and people were making reservations by letter. 1997.

@Birdyword @Whoozley I hand-wrote minutes and the pool secretary for our department typed and posted them. It was actually very efficient and we built projects nationwide in quicker timescales than achieved today.

@TonyMuller13 @Birdyword @eugeneh84 We didnt, we had a ghastly machine in a cupboard which dispensed the most revolting drinks, the top floor lot had a tea lady and cakes. We weren't allowed to have our own kettles but a lot of us did.

@Birdyword The biggest difference I remember (early 90s, training as a lawyer) was being able to send a letter and get a reply in days not hours. Meanwhile you’d free your brain to work on something else. Email transformed the stress levels. That and type it right the first time and BOOKS.
@csav55 @Birdyword @eugeneh84 And tea ladies.
@Birdyword I worked in publishing in 1986 when cutting and pasting meant exactly that. Each column was cut with a craft knife and glued onto a board... And everyone smoked apart from me ☹️
@mpntod @JackHillcox @Kav_Kaushik @Birdyword Yesssssss sweet memories. I remember asking if it was a bot
@Birdyword In 1885 you could post a letter and get a reply in a few hours, faster if you used a messenger.

@Birdyword My first office job was in 1986. It was the year my employer banned smoking in the office, except in designated smoking rooms. I recall many non-smokers being upset that smokers were permitted breaks to go smoke rather than smoke as they worked.
@patrickhadfield @Birdyword Horrible stuff. It had its use though! Survives, I think, in the metaphorical expression "carbon copy".

@Birdyword Computer printouts the size of doorsteps produced overnight. One person had access to a desktop computer that so many others were scared to use. Adding machines, separate typing pool and yes the offices were smokey. Tea ladies twice a day.

@Birdyword Worked with Guinness in the 90's and remember the first Marketing Manager who had the idea to save on admin by sending a large powerpoint by email to rep's laptops rather that have a big meeting. It cost over £3,000 in phone charges! They didn't try that again for a few years.
@Birdyword @eugeneh84 Pretty much, though we had word processors, fax machines, photocopiers, telephones and fags, it was much as it is in 2021 but with PC's.
@Birdyword Talking, typing, shouting into (landline) phones

@Birdyword I was in a newsroom. We picked up the phone and, y'know, talked to people. Verbally. In person, one to one. Found out more that way than my successors ever can telling audiences what someone has tweeted.

@Birdyword I come from the manual era of hand-cranked desk calculators and hand-written accounting spreadsheets in physical journals. Various methods of chemically duplicating documents arose as did electronic calculators. Then computers started to be able to store documents.

@Birdyword I was a journalist. I imagine we might have been out and about a bit more. In the office I thumped a big manual typewriter, had excellent spelling and grammar and used lots of paper. I also used shorthand. No smoking allowed in my office but yes, lots of typing, chatter and tea.
@JackHillcox @Zoah_HS @Kav_Kaushik @Birdyword Appears to still be in my phone directory! You texted your question to 63336 ...
@uccello_lirico @Birdyword Oh god *carbon paper*!!!
@Birdyword Faxing, telexing, photocopying, printing, telephoning and data entry on computer terminal connected to mainframe without having to deal with constant emails.

@AndyfromTucson @Birdyword Oh my goodness, I would love this so much - the time we would have to actually do some work if only emails took three days to get through! How many fewer of them there would be!
@leylandrichard @Birdyword I'm trying to work out if you're joking but of course you're not, are you!

@Birdyword By the time I started work @thetimes c’98, smoking had been relegated to the “smoker’s corner” at the end of the room. It was a tip but the best place for gossip. At the other end, there was a single computer hooked up to the internet but nobody used it.
@RTaylor_LibDem @Birdyword And photocopying *everything*!
@catherine_mayer @Birdyword @TheEconomist We had pub lunches regularly - more liquid than lunch, especially on Fridays if the office was quiet!
@mrrjwilson We had those in the BBC as well - till pretty recently, in fact. And faxes, spewing out thousands of 'never picked up' messages....
@Birdyword In the late 90’s I worked at an advertising agency that put out wine and cheese for board meetings.
@Tabby_Kinder Not even BBM? How did you [redacted] [redacted] [redacted]
@Birdyword @Helenarth Water cooler Tallis about sitcoms
@Birdyword Being told to go to Works and ask for a long stand; being given the number of London Zoo to ask for a seal... etc.

@Birdyword - Unjamming photocopier/dot matrix printer - Saying your extension number - Choosing your favourite month in the Pirelli calendar, ogling Page 3 and LOTS of general sexism - Kicking the vending machine - Friday afternoon in pub - Card indexes - Arguing over whose turn for teas
@Birdyword @Alby Lots of paper shuffling, typing with carbon copies, and index cards.
@Birdyword Yeah though I had a Nokia 3210 until I was like 17
@Tabby_Kinder Aren't we the same age? WTF

@Birdyword @alexhern Lots of paper files, floors of typists. Lots of letters into sacks of mail. Computer systems were databases full of reference numbers that were written on those letters and files.
@mpeterdavidson We called them ‘distribution envelopes’, worked a lot like email, but having to write in all the addresses tended to limit the distribution to who actually needed to see it.
@CMedtweetci @Birdyword this could be me... (if i earned enough from writing to afford the smoking habit i desperately stave off)
@Birdyword I remember having to text that 26662 (something like that anyway) number to solve an argument on a night out
@jrhopkin @Philippa_Carter @Birdyword Still did that in 2009... So much still hadn't been digitalized...
@Birdyword @JohnRentoul 🙄 “not” - obviously
@Birdyword @JohnRentoul All the time we saved by n it being on the internet / media we could use for a long lunch
@NNNPackdrill @Birdyword So companies have just swapped a massive typing pool for a massive IT pool?
@Zoah_HS @Kav_Kaushik @Birdyword This helped quite a few people in my year scrape a pass in their GCSEs

@Birdyword The fact that you can write "what people did in an office in say, 1985" indicates that you haven't got to grips with the chronology. By 1985 most medium-sized businesses were using computers of some sort. Calculators were on every desktop. The serious changes came earlier.
@Kav_Kaushik @Birdyword Was it AQA - Any Question Answered?!
@Birdyword 1985?! Try 1995. One telephone, one fax machine.

@Birdyword I worked in a cash office, even post-internet bank counters and post offices are still like this: double count and double enter cheques and cash, generate remittance slips for processing. There is also a lot of internal secure envelopes and pouches to send things for processes.
@Birdyword Now imagine an American technology university in the mid 70s where they have Internet access but are also likely smoking and using effectively typewriters.

@Birdyword I did a week of work experience in a local paper in the early 80s. Lots of phoning, and everything on the typewriter. I’ll never forget print day, when the machines seemed to make the wooden building shake!

@Birdyword I well remember in 1964 ringing the Central Library in Newcastle to ask about Palatine Bishops of Durham. The Librarian indicated he would happily maim the teacher who had set the question, which 15 schoolboys, so far, had rung up about

@Birdyword playing office cricket, chatting on the phone to mates, flirting, drinking tea from the tea trolley that still came round then - making paper planes, going to the pub at lunchtime, having a cheeky nap - good times

@Birdyword Working in a sailing club in 91 and the booking system, which might have been a spreadsheet, went down. So we sellotaped cardboard plus physical booking forms into a room-sized physical database.

@Birdyword My first office job was in 1990. Typing letters and minutes on an electric typewriter, with carbon paper in between for the copies. One mistake and the whole thing had to be retyped 😭 Lots of filing and transferring calls. Later (can't remember what year), we had Wang computers.

@Birdyword Yes. I worked on a magazine and that’s precisely what we did, along with trawling through cuttings in press libraries and receiving telegrams from journos overseas. We used the phone and wrote a lot of letters (on a manual typewriter) too.
@RosemontEmily @Birdyword And before the calculator (came in early 70s) with a slide rule or log tables.
@leecrawfurd @Birdyword they were referred to as accounting registers back in the 1970s and 80s. A lot of accounting students used these to learn debit and credit entries, etc.
@Birdyword My mother worked on Telex machines

@Birdyword Bank back office 1973. Copies of statements and all the cheques had to be filed. Balances of accounts on "watch list" copied from head office printout to a ledger so history could be tracked. There was some sort of computer system, but I didn't get to touch that.

@Birdyword @alexhern My first office data point is 1996, but I do remember we spent a lot of time buying junk food and chatting up the cashier in the garage next door, and also drinking in the pub next door to that. I'm guessing working while pissed on a Fri afternoon is no longer modern practice..?

@jackiewatson05 @wordspinster @Birdyword @unfortunatalie That was part of my job, from about 6.30 until 9ish, though it didn't stop with the advent of Google. Always better to read in print, as you find things you didn't know you were interested in. An online search narrows the perspective horribly.
@Birdyword Next tweet in my timeline was this... https://t.co/VFO2jI7kzs
@sookio @Birdyword In my first job - 1998 - we had tea ladies that came round twice daily, wearing tabards and pouring from a giant pot.

@Birdyword I worked in software dev in 1996, we did have a 64kb/s internet link, but we did also have shelves of paper manuals and magazines .. as well as a huge collection of MSDN CDs. I sort of miss offline reference sources :)
@Birdyword @alexhern My first job in school was for 60 pounds (Irish punts) a week to put away paper files in a travel and freight firm. Not even take them out of storage, just put them back in.
@jrhopkin @Birdyword Indeed - well I wouldn't like to guess how much of it got read the first time round...it was a good opportunity for procrastination.
@Philippa_Carter @Birdyword I spent months reading through microfiches. That was a lot of fun
@MATruman @Ray_McCann55 @Birdyword @PeteTaxMiller I worked in an accounting practice. We had a dedicated file room with paper based files. We even settled matters over the phone back then! Cute!
@MATruman @Birdyword Expertly explained 👏👏👏👏👏

@Ray_McCann55 @Birdyword Enter the BF system, which came from a staff suggestion. You wrote “BF 4” on it with your initials. The filing clerks had tags in four colours that stuck out of the files. They put this week’s colour tag in it; 4 wks later that colour identified all the files to distribute. 2/2
@Philippa_Carter @Birdyword You would have spent even more time and money photocopying things, and probably not reading half of them ;)
@hustlersconvent @DuncanWeldon @Birdyword But yet we still make people work significant overtime, pack schedules with pointless meetings. Never underestimate humanity's ability to create busywork.

@jrhopkin @Birdyword As an undergrad 2000-04 I spent a VERY long time (and quite a lot of cash) photocopying journal articles from the huge bound versions in the library. Doing a PhD now and don't know how anyone managed it pre-internet

@hustlersconvent @DuncanWeldon @Birdyword Very much. So many menial office tasks that would have otherwise taken hours by hand can now be automated away by a single Excel macro (or whatever) You could probably spend a whole day mailing physical letters/leaflets that could be handled by email automation now, and so on..

@Ray_McCann55 @Birdyword OK, so Ray, I, and @PeteTaxMiller worked for the Inland Revenue. Taxpayer files were kept in racks, and had to go back there when not used. If you wrote a letter to the taxpayer or agent and needed a reminder to check whether they had replied, what did you do? 1/2
@Birdyword Must have still had a steel industry then too 😳
@Birdyword Acrylic jumpers and drawing boards. Not a computer in sight. https://t.co/HRRa2mNVRH
@v_j_freeman @Birdyword 1985 we had mainframe computers for the heavy lifting, dedicated word-processors, nascent PCs and joy of joys, a fax machine to replace telex.
@MATruman @Birdyword No, I shall leave that pleasure to you, when I took over SIS 2 they BF’d for six months, which was fine other than the time expired in three!

@lizmorrish @jrhopkin @Birdyword I prefer physical books, have gone back to writing by hand (or occasionally with an Apple pencil) for research and I still try to have audio calls whenever possible. I am happy I don’t have to use the card catalogue in the library any more, though.
@Birdyword Oh! We also sent notes to different floors via vacuum tubes which blew my mind.

@Birdyword My first job in 1997 was typesetting birth and death notices for a local paper. We did it on computer but had to code the indents, pictures, and bold copy. It was also my job to take the paper off the printer (with perforated holes down each side) and take it to the print dept.

@Birdyword I worked in a technical drawing office from 1975 to 1980. Basically lots of paperwork, filling in forms with actual biros. Filing forms into metal cabinets. Drawing components on paper with actual pencils, printing out blueprints for the factory downstairs.
@Ray_McCann55 @Birdyword “BF 4 weeks”… Do you want to explain, Ray,,or shall I?!
@Ray_McCann55 @MATruman @Birdyword And copies were made using carbon paper!
@Birdyword @InterfloraUK I loved the job, btw. It was really great 🌸🌺🌼

@Birdyword @InterfloraUK To the office itself… No smoking was allowed! We had staggered tea breaks for 15 mins in the morning and afternoon. We’d go to the ‘rest room’, where a woman would pour tea from a massive metal pot into rows of cups. There was also a selection of biscuits. I miss tea breaks…

@Birdyword @InterfloraUK Information came from the Interflora directory of florists - an alphabetical list by place name in a frequently-edited book. Other info - e.g. special offers/promotions in newspapers, typical ranges for rose prices around the country - were pinned to the boards around our desks
@Birdyword @InterfloraUK This was using a credit card machine much like the ones we use today in shops. Though it was a single machine, plugged into the wall that only one of us could use at a time

@Birdyword @InterfloraUK If an order was for a mixed bouquet for £25, easy. If it was for a set number of rose stems, prices fluctuated too much to know the price. So we had to ‘phone the delivery florist to check how much they’d be and ring the customer back to check it was ok and take payment
@Birdyword @InterfloraUK Someone would ‘phone the orders through to florists around the country. International orders were given to the telex operator

@Birdyword @InterfloraUK We took orders from the public over the ‘phone. They’d call in with UK/international orders and we’d write out all the details on the order pads. We’d also determine the nearest florist for delivery (that’s when I learned there were two St Ives very far away from each other…)

@Birdyword @InterfloraUK In the morning, someone would take the reams of paper off the telex machines, which were orders from overseas for UK delivery, which had come in overnight. These had to be separated (by tearing along a ruler edge) and all written onto triplicate order pads

@Birdyword I worked @InterfloraUK HQ 🌸🌺🌼as a weekend/holiday job late 80s into early 90s). We mainly used pens, paper, ‘phones, faxes & telex machines (bar those working on ‘retrans’ - ? - upstairs which were *actual computers* for taking international orders from florists)

@Birdyword (JWT Ad agency mid 80s) - ordering copies of commercials on U Matic (recorded by video cam off air!); cuttings dept reading press/mags and filing stories for research; whole dept tasked with creating artwork for pitches; (3m spray adhesive! The smell!) On the phone - all day.

@Birdyword 'Routing envelopes' for all internal messaging; usually filled with typed up 'call reports' with details of any client conversation; rotary dial phones with clients on 3 digit speed codes; dictaphones and sucking up to secretaries to do yours first, or at least, by end of day.
@wordspinster @Birdyword @unfortunatalie Me too! Amazing how younger people just don't know the alphabet properly and can't put things in order correctly!!
@Birdyword @FBantor Possibly why I stopped going to the pub with my school mates. Old enough to be aware of the Tories but too busy arguing about what Simon Le Bon’s favourite breed of dog is.

@Birdyword @Markla94 Wrote things down with pen and paper, read books and reports, communicated by telephone. For offical reports and abstracts we had a department with about 10 secretaries who tried to copy our ugly writing into typing machines.

@Birdyword @FBantor Although when I first went to pubs it was as a 16 year old in 1989 and my friends would only ever tend to argue about what some pop or rock star had or hadn’t done or did/didn’t like and it was always settled by someone in the group who had “read in Smash Hits last week that…”
@Birdyword @FBantor It was much easier back then. It either developed into a fist fight or the situation was diffused by someone telling a horrifyingly racist or ableist joke.
@Birdyword I’d be genuinely fascinated to watch Back In Time for Work about how offices functioned in the recent past. I’m quite surprised it hasn’t been done in fact
@Birdyword Secretaries typed. We smoked and passed around pieces of paper a lot

@Birdyword I started in an office in 1989. Internal phones were shared. Only the supervisor had an external line. VDUs attached to a mainframe (our dept was advanced!). One stand-alone PC with displaywrite4. @desk smoking our of core hours. Women not allowed to wear trousers 🙄
@Birdyword ... nobody typed unless you were a secretary/in admin. Everyone else dictated or wrote on a pad. And yes, smoking at desks.😱
@PolemicTMM @kitjuckes @DuncanWeldon @Birdyword Yeah, totally great time for women in the workplace.

@Birdyword Did work experience in an engineering company in 1987. Sales engineers wrote memos/letters with a pen, then then admin staff typed them up and sent them. Admin staff had computers but no internet and I don't think any network. Computer was basically an advanced typewriter...

@Birdyword one of my mates first jobs was being an sms service for this. you’d text a phone number and then he’d look the answer up in a book/early internet to settle pub disputes. he said it was really popular
@MATruman @Birdyword And getting really irritated at the fax machine! Then there was tons of written correspondence, literally tons of it.

@Birdyword I've worked in offices since the early 00s, and frankly a lot has changed just in that time. Saying that, I was speaking to a friends mum about this stuff and she worked in an office in the late 70s collating spreadsheet data to be input into a mainframe, so not THAT different!

@Birdyword Funny. I am a computer programmer, and I have little trouble to imagine office life/work before. Of course, it entails slaving away at lots of minutiae that have been automated. But also a lot more human communication in the process. Late payment? Phone! etc
@Birdyword We stood at the fax machine for hours and waited for things to come in the post. Nothing was urgent.
@Birdyword I first worked in an office in 1988. I had a computer on my desk.
@discountinvestr @DuncanWeldon @Birdyword + Drug Wars

@Birdyword The documents were shorter and simpler, rather than making changes directly to documents people would make manuscript changes and then ask a secretary to type them up. They would then be couriered/faxed to someone else!

@AndyfromTucson @Birdyword I caught someone faxing something in our office last year. Was absolutely wild. All of the interns (early 20s) came to watch it be sent and learn our old ways. Apparently, mortgage companies in the US still need you to fax stuff rather than email a pdf.

@PhilipBBerman @Birdyword Email, mostly internal, but some intercompany, was up and running in the late 80s Companies like CompuServe were providing dial up business services Hard to have had web access before Tim B-L published the first paper in 1989

@Birdyword In the end we had a designated smoking room. It was packed, and very smoky. I remember my first laptop, and being taught how to use a fax machine. And the mobile brick, now known as a mobile phone. We gathered round in awe.
@wordspinster @Birdyword @unfortunatalie I was doing this with student scripts as late as 2012.

@Birdyword My first office job was in 1995, scanning paper as the surveyor I worked for had just got computers. There were still paper files so I also spent a ton of time filing/photocopying. You could also smoke/drink at your desk so upsides/downsides.
@Birdyword My massive concern with email: people just ignore them! So often I fwd it again a week later with “can I get an update to the below please?” Drives me absolutely bonkers!
@Birdyword You know all those emails you send and receive? That, but as conversations on the phone.

@DuncanWeldon @Birdyword I think things just took longer so easier to fill 7.5 hours with "work" that included handwriting letters and complex schedules by hand, walking back and forth to the typist, checking other people's complex calculations with a calculator. I started in 1986.
@Birdyword https://t.co/IawWl8bDax

@Birdyword Small municipal office: answering phone, logging constituent calls, opening/ sorting mail, typing correspondence & forms with carbon copy tissue, opening boxes of pubs of the latest guidelines for fire department ops and sorting into a shelf of binders designed for purpose…
@Birdyword I recall very early word word processors around 1987 which sometimes burst into flames. Printers were so loud they had glass covers.

@Birdyword My father was an engineer (power stations & oil rigs mostly). I remember going into their offices in the 80s. They had to draw out everything by hand rather than on CAD and mostly do all their calculations with a small calculator, pen, paper & their brains.

@Birdyword Thinking about my office (cubicle) in 1986, not so different. But courier was only typeface, dot matrix printers spewed memos on perforated green/white sheets, and the coveted 300MB platter stack was size of kitchen sink
@gareth_in_blyth @wordspinster @Birdyword @unfortunatalie He was! I seem to remember big scrap books whizzing their way to Euan Balfour every day…
@Ranavalona111 @Birdyword Omg! yes your right.
@Birdyword Faxing, lots of faxing documents

@Birdyword We were slightly more productive & social before internet than after. We also listened to the same radio station with golden oldies and hits of the day. Loathed it passionately. Then there was office politics & hating your colleagues. Took a lot of time 2. Drank same bad coffee.
@DuncanWeldon @Birdyword I had a temp job in 2004 that was the same. Spent a lot of time reading about pig prices on the intranet.
@mippy @PhilipBBerman @Birdyword Yes, I didn't know until hours later (mind you I am not glued to the web now either -- but that's me 🙂) after I got home and put the radio on.
@kitjuckes @DuncanWeldon @Birdyword And freely offending each other, or trying to, but people didn't appear to get offended back then. Those were the days
@Birdyword I do find it extraordinary to think back to the job I had at the local newspaper and how my boss used to sometimes smoke at her desk. The thought of me coming into work and doing that now!
@jackiewatson05 @wordspinster @Birdyword @unfortunatalie I imagine he was quite deft with scissors and a pritt stick as he did the manual version of control x / control V...

@JudSawyer @PhilipBBerman @Birdyword On 9/11, I was a student and going out with someone who worked in an office. He came round to mine after work and had no idea what had happened until he came in and saw our TV. Sounds so primitive now!
@Birdyword Rest assured that your children and grandchildren will also wonder what you did all day as well.

@wordspinster @Birdyword @unfortunatalie When I talk to colleagues about change I usually start with 'the first bank I worked in had one computer, four phone lines and thirty staff' before telling them to try and count how many computers any office has now.
@Birdyword (Also, following because we share a birthday!)
@whatsinitforme @v_j_freeman @Birdyword Letters (in triplicate, one for the clt, one for the file, one for the diary) and phone calls and meetings.
@Birdyword When I started my broadcast job in the 00s we had to get the files we needed biked round to us on physical media in order to get them ingested onto our system. Even that seems quaint now!

@Birdyword We had women in typing pool typing letters with carbon copies. The accounts girls used ledger machines that were like playing an organ and I remember I stamped a lot of things and used glue all day long.

@DuncanWeldon @Birdyword Tippex and real printing firms; fewer distractions from dealing room banter… buying/selling boxes of shampoo or bananas or any random thing someone might make a two-way price in. And laughs when someone finally had to take physical delivery. And people smoking in offices.
@Birdyword These things. https://t.co/oY5lQYaMpN

@jackiewatson05 @jamesrosscomedy @wordspinster @Birdyword @unfortunatalie It’s true. I recently joined a company who have an AI system which reads millions of news articles/day, from all over the world, looking for people/places/topics etc it’s been trained to spot. It can even judge the sentiment behind each mention. It’s both cool and spooky.

@Birdyword Phone calls, faxing was a real thing, filing paperwork. Typing letters, reports and posting numerous copies everywhere. Driving to the main post office to get the last post. I also remember somebody giving us training on sending emails.
@Uncivil_S @Birdyword Photostat surely?

@Birdyword I did office work from 1992 to 2001 without internet access. I always used a VDU which was linked up to all the others in the room / building via a server. We could generally email each other but not the outside world, which we had to phone or fax. The photocopier was king.
@Birdyword In 1985, we said the same about photocopiers.

@Birdyword I once had to install Windows on a PC from a set of floppy disks as not all PCs came with a CD unit. From memory it was somewhere around 20 disks and I think I lost the will to work there somewhere around disk 6.
